EEG\n  - real-time EEG; online EEG; continuous EEG; streaming EEG\n  - EEG feature extraction; EEG features; EEG biomarkers\n  - EEG decoding; brain-state decoding; state estimation (EEG); brain state classification (EEG)\n  - EEG phase; phase estimation; phase tracking; phase-locked (EEG)\n  - EEG oscillations; neural oscillations (EEG); rhythmic activity (EEG)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include both “decoding” and “feature extraction/biomarker” language because relevant papers may avoid the term “decode.”\n  - “Phase/oscillation” terms are included because timing control of stimulation is commonly described via phase/oscillatory state rather than generic “brain state.”\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation as the Controlled Intervention (Output Actuator)\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where the intervention being adaptively controlled is TMS (not other stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation; TMS\n  - magnetic stimulation; transcranial magnetic pulse(s)\n  - single-pulse TMS; paired-pulse TMS; repetitive TMS; rTMS\n  - TMS intensity; stimulation intensity (TMS); stimulator output\n  - stimulation timing (TMS); pulse timing; trigger timing; inter-pulse interval (when explicitly tied to TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Keep TMS-specific parameter language (timing/intensity) because some papers emphasize “triggering” or “dose” without repeating “closed-loop” terminology.\n\n### Block C: Closed-loop / Feedback / Adaptive Control Linking EEG to TMS (Control Architecture)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work is genuinely closed-loop: EEG-derived information is used to adapt TMS parameters in real time via feedback/adaptive control.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop; closed loop; closed-loop stimulation\n  - feedback control; feedback; control algorithm; controller\n  - adaptive stimulation; adaptive control; real-time adaptation\n  - state-dependent stimulation; brain-state–dependent stimulation; state-locked stimulation\n  - EEG-triggered TMS; EEG-guided TMS; EEG-informed TMS\n  - responsive stimulation; contingent stimulation; event-triggered stimulation (when tied to EEG/TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include both “closed-loop” and “state-dependent/EEG-triggered” phrasing because many relevant papers describe the mechanism without using “closed-loop.”\n  - “Control algorithm/controller” terms capture engineering/control-focused papers that may not foreground “neuromodulation” keywords.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve (A) real-time EEG-derived features/brain-state decoding, (B) TMS as the stimulation modality, and (C) a closed-loop/feedback/adaptive control scheme where EEG information adjusts TMS timing and/or intensity.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop neuromodulation where EEG features are decoded online to adaptively control TMS parameters (especially timing and/or intensity), including design/evaluation of feedback control algorithms.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS studies (no EEG-based adaptation).\n  - EEG studies without TMS (e.g., EEG-only decoding/BCI without stimulation).\n  - Closed-loop stimulation using non-TMS modalities (e.g., tACS/tDCS, DBS, VNS, ultrasound) even if EEG-driven.\n  - Offline EEG analyses used only to plan TMS protocols without real-time/online adaptation.\n  - Studies where adaptation is driven by non-EEG signals (e.g., EMG, behavior, fMRI) unless EEG is the controlling input."}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:05:24.154794+00:00", "event": "phase1.adjust_framework.prompt", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "3af75f817df8", "model": "gpt-5.2", "reasoning_effort": "high", "prompt_file": "/Users/xiaowu/local_code/scholarmap/prompts/retrival_framework_stage2.md", "prompt": "You are an expert academic search strategist specializing in exhaustive literature retrieval. \n\nYou will receive:\n(1) The current Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n(2) User's adjustment request (user_additional_info) - may contain clarifications, modifications, or additional requirements\n\nYour task is to integrate the user's input with the current framework and produce an updated Conceptual Retrieval Framework that reflects the user's adjustments while maintaining the framework's integrity and searchability.\n\n-- current framework begin --\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: EEG-based Real-time Brain-State Decoding (Input Signal)\n- Concept Role: Captures literature where ongoing EEG is measured and features/brain state are extracted for online use (the sensing/decoding side of the loop).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography; EEG\n  - real-time EEG; online EEG; continuous EEG; streaming EEG\n  - EEG feature extraction; EEG features; EEG biomarkers\n  - EEG decoding; brain-state decoding; state estimation (EEG); brain state classification (EEG)\n  - EEG phase; phase estimation; phase tracking; phase-locked (EEG)\n  - EEG oscillations; neural oscillations (EEG); rhythmic activity (EEG)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include both “decoding” and “feature extraction/biomarker” language because relevant papers may avoid the term “decode.”\n  - “Phase/oscillation” terms are included because timing control of stimulation is commonly described via phase/oscillatory state rather than generic “brain state.”\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation as the Controlled Intervention (Output Actuator)\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where the intervention being adaptively controlled is TMS (not other stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation; TMS\n  - magnetic stimulation; transcranial magnetic pulse(s)\n  - single-pulse TMS; paired-pulse TMS; repetitive TMS; rTMS\n  - TMS intensity; stimulation intensity (TMS); stimulator output\n  - stimulation timing (TMS); pulse timing; trigger timing; inter-pulse interval (when explicitly tied to TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Keep TMS-specific parameter language (timing/intensity) because some papers emphasize “triggering” or “dose” without repeating “closed-loop” terminology.\n\n### Block C: Closed-loop / Feedback / Adaptive Control Linking EEG to TMS (Control Architecture)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work is genuinely closed-loop: EEG-derived information is used to adapt TMS parameters in real time via feedback/adaptive control.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop; closed loop; closed-loop stimulation\n  - feedback control; feedback; control algorithm; controller\n  - adaptive stimulation; adaptive control; real-time adaptation\n  - state-dependent stimulation; brain-state–dependent stimulation; state-locked stimulation\n  - EEG-triggered TMS; EEG-guided TMS; EEG-informed TMS\n  - responsive stimulation; contingent stimulation; event-triggered stimulation (when tied to EEG/TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include both “closed-loop” and “state-dependent/EEG-triggered” phrasing because many relevant papers describe the mechanism without using “closed-loop.”\n  - “Control algorithm/controller” terms capture engineering/control-focused papers that may not foreground “neuromodulation” keywords.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve (A) real-time EEG-derived features/brain-state decoding, (B) TMS as the stimulation modality, and (C) a closed-loop/feedback/adaptive control scheme where EEG information adjusts TMS timing and/or intensity.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop neuromodulation where EEG features are decoded online to adaptively control TMS parameters (especially timing and/or intensity), including design/evaluation of feedback control algorithms.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS studies (no EEG-based adaptation).\n  - EEG studies without TMS (e.g., EEG-only decoding/BCI without stimulation).\n  - Closed-loop stimulation using non-TMS modalities (e.g., tACS/tDCS, DBS, VNS, ultrasound) even if EEG-driven.\n  - Offline EEG analyses used only to plan TMS protocols without real-time/online adaptation.\n  - Studies where adaptation is driven by non-EEG signals (e.g., EMG, behavior, fMRI) unless EEG is the controlling input.\n-- current framework end --\n\nuser_additional_info (user's adjustment request):\n\"\"\"The out-of-scope need to be adjusted. No only the online EEG analysis, offline EEG analysis should also be included.\"\"\"\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Base the updated framework on BOTH the current framework AND the user's adjustment request.\n   - Preserve valid parts of the current framework that are not contradicted by the user's input.\n   - Incorporate the user's adjustments, clarifications, or modifications.\n   - Do NOT introduce entirely new research goals or domains that are not mentioned in either the current framework or user input.\n\n2. The output must define a SMALL NUMBER of concept blocks (typically 2–4).\n   - Each block represents a distinct and independently searchable conceptual dimension\n     that should not be merged with other dimensions if doing so would reduce recall.\n   - Examples include: research task, technical field/framing, data modality.\n   - All blocks together must uniquely define ONE narrow research field.\n\nIMPORTANT — Concept Block Separation Rule:\n\nWhen constructing concept blocks, prioritize retrieval independence over semantic compactness.\n\nIf two concepts frequently appear separately in relevant literature\n(e.g., one may be mentioned without the other in titles/abstracts),\nthey MUST be placed in separate concept blocks,\neven if they form a well-known combined phrase or subfield name.\n\nExample:\n- \"speech\" and \"brain-computer interface\" must be separate blocks,\n  because many relevant papers mention speech decoding without explicitly using \"BCI\",\n  and others mention BCI without explicitly using \"speech\".\n\n3. Each concept block must:\n   - Contain only terms that are conceptually equivalent within that block.\n   - Be expressed using terminology commonly found in academic databases.\n   - Include common synonyms, abbreviations, and canonical terms used in the literature.\n\n4. When the user input or current framework uses abstract or high-level language, normalize it into concrete, database-searchable concepts\n   ONLY when such normalization is standard practice in the field.\n   - Example: \"invasive recordings\" → ECoG, sEEG, intracortical recordings, MEA\n   - Do NOT introduce loosely related or adjacent techniques.\n\n5. All concept blocks must be REQUIRED.\n   - The framework should be designed for exhaustive retrieval within a specific field,\n     not for exploratory or cross-domain search.\n\n6. Do NOT generate executable Boolean queries.\n   - You MAY describe the logical relationship between blocks conceptually\n     (e.g., \"documents must address all blocks simultaneously\"),\n     but do not use database syntax.\n\n7. Explicitly prevent topic drift.\n   - The framework should clearly exclude adjacent but distinct research areas.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n### Block B: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n(Repeat blocks as needed)\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nA single sentence explaining how all blocks jointly define the target literature set.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n- Out-of-scope:\n\n"}

Online or Offline)\n- Concept Role: Captures literature where EEG is analyzed to derive features/biomarkers/brain-state information that is used to determine or tailor TMS delivery; includes both real-time/online decoding and offline EEG analyses used to set state-dependent rules or individualized stimulation parameters.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography; EEG\n  - EEG analysis; EEG signal processing\n  - EEG feature extraction; EEG features; EEG biomarkers; EEG markers\n  - EEG decoding; brain-state decoding; brain state classification (EEG); state estimation (EEG)\n  - EEG oscillations; neural oscillations (EEG); rhythmic activity (EEG)\n  - EEG phase; phase estimation; phase tracking; phase-locked (EEG)\n  - online EEG; real-time EEG; continuous EEG; streaming EEG\n  - offline EEG; post hoc EEG; offline analysis; retrospective EEG analysis\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Keep both “decoding” and “feature/biomarker” language to capture papers that avoid “decode.”\n  - Explicitly include “offline EEG” terms to retrieve studies where EEG is analyzed offline to define state-dependent stimulation rules (even if stimulation itself is not adaptively updated moment-to-moment).\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Intervention (Output Actuator)\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where the stimulation modality being delivered/parameterized is TMS.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation; TMS\n  - magnetic stimulation; transcranial magnetic pulse(s)\n  - single-pulse TMS; paired-pulse TMS; repetitive TMS; rTMS\n  - TMS intensity; stimulation intensity (TMS); stimulator output\n  - stimulation timing (TMS); pulse timing; trigger timing; inter-pulse interval (when explicitly tied to TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include parameter terms (timing/intensity/triggering) because many papers emphasize dosing/triggering rather than “closed-loop.”\n\n### Block C: EEG-Informed Control/Linking Architecture for TMS (Closed-loop or Precomputed State-Dependent Rules)\n- Concept Role: Ensures EEG-derived information is explicitly used to control, guide, trigger, or parameterize TMS delivery—either via real-time feedback/adaptive control (closed-loop) or via offline-derived, EEG-informed state-dependent stimulation rules applied during TMS.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop; closed loop; closed-loop stimulation\n  - feedback control; feedback; control algorithm; controller\n  - adaptive stimulation; adaptive control; real-time adaptation\n  - state-dependent stimulation; brain-state–dependent stimulation; state-locked stimulation\n  - EEG-triggered TMS; EEG-guided TMS; EEG-informed TMS\n  - responsive stimulation; contingent stimulation; event-triggered stimulation (when tied to EEG/TMS)\n  - phase-triggered TMS; phase-locked TMS; oscillation-triggered TMS\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Retain classic closed-loop/control terms for true online adaptation.\n  - Also retain “EEG-guided/EEG-informed/state-dependent” phrasing to capture studies where EEG is analyzed offline to define stimulation timing/intensity rules that are then applied during TMS sessions.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve (A) EEG-derived features/brain-state information (online or offline), (B) TMS, and (C) an explicit architecture where EEG information guides/triggers/parameterizes TMS delivery (via closed-loop feedback or offline-derived state-dependent rules).\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-informed TMS where EEG features/brain state (including oscillatory phase) are used to determine TMS timing and/or intensity.\n  - True closed-loop EEG–TMS systems with real-time EEG processing and adaptive/feedback control.\n  - EEG-guided/state-dependent TMS where EEG is analyzed offline to define individualized or state-contingent stimulation rules that are then used to deliver TMS.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - TMS studies with no EEG-based guidance/triggering/parameterization (pure open-loop TMS with fixed schedules not derived from EEG).\n  - EEG studies without TMS.\n  - Closed-loop or EEG-guided stimulation using non-TMS modalities (tACS/tDCS, DBS, VNS, ultrasound), even if EEG-driven.\n  - Adaptation/guidance driven solely by non-EEG signals (e.g., EMG, behavior, fMRI) unless EEG is explicitly the controlling or rule-defining input.", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "3af75f817df8", "step": "adjust_framework"}

Online or Offline)\n- Concept Role: Captures literature where EEG is analyzed to derive features/biomarkers/brain-state information that is used to determine or tailor TMS delivery; includes both real-time/online decoding and offline EEG analyses used to set state-dependent rules or individualized stimulation parameters.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography; EEG\n  - EEG analysis; EEG signal processing\n  - EEG feature extraction; EEG features; EEG biomarkers; EEG markers\n  - EEG decoding; brain-state decoding; brain state classification (EEG); state estimation (EEG)\n  - EEG oscillations; neural oscillations (EEG); rhythmic activity (EEG)\n  - EEG phase; phase estimation; phase tracking; phase-locked (EEG)\n  - online EEG; real-time EEG; continuous EEG; streaming EEG\n  - offline EEG; post hoc EEG; offline analysis; retrospective EEG analysis\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Keep both “decoding” and “feature/biomarker” language to capture papers that avoid “decode.”\n  - Explicitly include “offline EEG” terms to retrieve studies where EEG is analyzed offline to define state-dependent stimulation rules (even if stimulation itself is not adaptively updated moment-to-moment).\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Intervention (Output Actuator)\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where the stimulation modality being delivered/parameterized is TMS.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation; TMS\n  - magnetic stimulation; transcranial magnetic pulse(s)\n  - single-pulse TMS; paired-pulse TMS; repetitive TMS; rTMS\n  - TMS intensity; stimulation intensity (TMS); stimulator output\n  - stimulation timing (TMS); pulse timing; trigger timing; inter-pulse interval (when explicitly tied to TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include parameter terms (timing/intensity/triggering) because many papers emphasize dosing/triggering rather than “closed-loop.”\n\n### Block C: EEG-Informed Control/Linking Architecture for TMS (Closed-loop or Precomputed State-Dependent Rules)\n- Concept Role: Ensures EEG-derived information is explicitly used to control, guide, trigger, or parameterize TMS delivery—either via real-time feedback/adaptive control (closed-loop) or via offline-derived, EEG-informed state-dependent stimulation rules applied during TMS.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop; closed loop; closed-loop stimulation\n  - feedback control; feedback; control algorithm; controller\n  - adaptive stimulation; adaptive control; real-time adaptation\n  - state-dependent stimulation; brain-state–dependent stimulation; state-locked stimulation\n  - EEG-triggered TMS; EEG-guided TMS; EEG-informed TMS\n  - responsive stimulation; contingent stimulation; event-triggered stimulation (when tied to EEG/TMS)\n  - phase-triggered TMS; phase-locked TMS; oscillation-triggered TMS\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Retain classic closed-loop/control terms for true online adaptation.\n  - Also retain “EEG-guided/EEG-informed/state-dependent” phrasing to capture studies where EEG is analyzed offline to define stimulation timing/intensity rules that are then applied during TMS sessions.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve (A) EEG-derived features/brain-state information (online or offline), (B) TMS, and (C) an explicit architecture where EEG information guides/triggers/parameterizes TMS delivery (via closed-loop feedback or offline-derived state-dependent rules).\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-informed TMS where EEG features/brain state (including oscillatory phase) are used to determine TMS timing and/or intensity.\n  - True closed-loop EEG–TMS systems with real-time EEG processing and adaptive/feedback control.\n  - EEG-guided/state-dependent TMS where EEG is analyzed offline to define individualized or state-contingent stimulation rules that are then used to deliver TMS.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - TMS studies with no EEG-based guidance/triggering/parameterization (pure open-loop TMS with fixed schedules not derived from EEG).\n  - EEG studies without TMS.\n  - Closed-loop or EEG-guided stimulation using non-TMS modalities (tACS/tDCS, DBS, VNS, ultrasound), even if EEG-driven.\n  - Adaptation/guidance driven solely by non-EEG signals (e.g., EMG, behavior, fMRI) unless EEG is explicitly the controlling or rule-defining input."}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:11:15.441903+00:00", "event": "parse.stage1.prompt", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "model": "gpt-5.2", "reasoning_effort": "high", "prompt_file": "/Users/xiaowu/local_code/scholarmap/prompts/parse_stage1_understanding.md", "prompt": "你是“研究描述理解与规范化”模块。输入是一段纯文本候选研究描述。你的目标是帮助用户把研究描述变得合理且清晰，便于后续生成文献检索查询。\n\n你必须完成：\n1) 判断这段描述是不是关于一类研究方向的描述，还是其他（比如小说，诗歌，日志等）。如果是研究描述就返回is_research_description=true.\n2) 如果是研究描述,进行常识可行性判断（plausibility_level）：\n- A_impossible：明显荒诞/违背当前科技常识（无法形成合理检索任务）\n- B_plausible：合理可行\n3) 如果合理可行，给出你对该研究描述的“当前理解”（normalized_understanding），用规范化、聚焦、可检索的英语重写，\n4) 判断当前理解是否已经清晰到可以用于检索；若不清晰，列出你仍不确定的点（疑问清单），并提出最多3个澄清问题（问题必须具体可回答）。\n5) 输出结构化提要（最小可检索闭包字段）：\ndomain, task, subject_system, methods, scope, intent, exclusions\n6) 只输出JSON，不输出任何额外文本。\n\n候选研究描述：\n\"\"\"I focus on closed-loop neural modulation based on the EEG signals.\"\"\"\n\n请严格按以下schema输出JSON：\n{\n  \"is_research_description\": boolean,\n  \"plausibility_level\": \"A_impossible\" | \"B_plausible\",\n  \"is_clear_for_search\": boolean,\n  \"normalized_understanding\": string,\n  \"structured_summary\": {\n    \"domain\": string | null,\n    \"task\": string | null,\n    \"subject_system\": string | null,\n    \"methods\": string | null,\n    \"scope\": string | null,\n    \"intent\": string | null,\n    \"exclusions\": string | null\n  },\n  \"uncertainties\": [string],\n  \"missing_fields\": [\"domain\",\"task\",\"subject_system\",\"methods\",\"scope\",\"intent\",\"exclusions\"],\n  \"suggested_questions\": [\n    {\"field\":\"domain|task|subject_system|methods|scope|intent|exclusions\", \"question\": string},\n    {\"field\":\"...\", \"question\": string},\n    {\"field\":\"...\", \"question\": string}\n  ]\n}\n\n约束：\n- 用英文回答。\n- 如果is_research_description = false，则\n  - I am interested in systems that extract real-time features from ongoing EEG and adapt TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters accordingly to modulate brain states. The work broadly concerns algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of EEG–TMS closed-loop paradigms, without committing to a single clinical or cognitive application, outcome metric, or subject population.\",\n  \"structured_summary\": {\n    \"domain\": \"Closed-loop neuromodulation; EEG-guided TMS\",\n    \"task\": \"Design and evaluate real-time control loops that adapt TMS based on EEG-derived brain-state estimates\",\n    \"subject_system\": \"Unspecified (could be healthy humans, patient cohorts, or animal models); EEG unspecified (scalp vs intracranial)\",\n    \"methods\": \"Real-time EEG signal processing/feature extraction, state estimation, adaptive control/optimization, closed-loop TMS parameter scheduling; experimental validation\",\n    \"scope\": \"General-purpose EEG–TMS closed-loop frameworks across potential applications\",\n    \"intent\": \"Modulate neural activity/brain state by adjusting TMS in response to ongoing EEG\",\n    \"exclusions\": \"Not specified; application/outcome, success metrics, and target population are intentionally unconstrained\"\n  },\n  \"uncertainties\": [\n    \"The primary application/outcome and success metrics are unspecified, making it hard to define evaluation criteria for search.\",\n    \"The target subjects/setting and EEG modality/channel configuration are unspecified, which strongly affects relevant literature (e.g., scalp EEG vs intracranial, online artifact handling).\",\n    \"The specific closed-loop control target is unclear (e.g., phase-locked stimulation, state-dependent gating, adaptive intensity/frequency, or protocol selection).\"\n  ],\n  \"missing_fields\": [\n    \"task\",\n    \"subject_system\",\n    \"methods\",\n    \"scope\",\n    \"intent\",\n    \"exclusions\"\n  ],\n  \"suggested_questions\": [\n    {\n      \"field\": \"task\",\n      \"question\": \"What is the closed-loop control objective for EEG-guided TMS (e.g., phase-locked stimulation, state-dependent triggering, adaptive intensity/frequency, or protocol selection)?\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"field\": \"subject_system\",\n      \"question\": \"Which subject population and EEG setup do you assume for your core work (healthy vs specific disorder; scalp EEG channel count; online artifact mitigation for TMS-EEG)?\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"field\": \"scope\",\n      \"question\": \"Do you want the scope to emphasize methodological contributions (algorithms/control/real-time systems) or a particular application domain (e.g., depression, motor recovery, attention, epilepsy)?\"\n    }\n  ]\n}", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "stage": "stage2"}

application/outcome, success metrics, and target population are intentionally unconstrained\"\n  },\n  \"uncertainties\": [\n    \"The primary application/outcome and success metrics are unspecified, making it hard to define evaluation criteria for search.\",\n    \"The target subjects/setting and EEG modality/channel configuration are unspecified, which strongly affects relevant literature (e.g., scalp EEG vs intracranial, online artifact handling).\",\n    \"The specific closed-loop control target is unclear (e.g., phase-locked stimulation, state-dependent gating, adaptive intensity/frequency, or protocol selection).\"\n  ],\n  \"missing_fields\": [\n    \"task\",\n    \"subject_system\",\n    \"methods\",\n    \"scope\",\n    \"intent\",\n    \"exclusions\"\n  ],\n  \"suggested_questions\": [\n    {\n      \"field\": \"task\",\n      \"question\": \"What is the closed-loop control objective for EEG-guided TMS (e.g., phase-locked stimulation, state-dependent triggering, adaptive intensity/frequency, or protocol selection)?\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"field\": \"subject_system\",\n      \"question\": \"Which subject population and EEG setup do you assume for your core work (healthy vs specific disorder; {"ts": "2026-01-03T03:17:07.063740+00:00", "event": "phase1.parse.prompt", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "model": "gpt-5.2", "reasoning_effort": "high", "prompt": "You are an expert academic search strategist specializing in exhaustive literature retrieval. \n\nBelow is a short research summary, your task is to take above research summary and directly produce a conceptual retrieval framework that can be used to systematically search for all relevant literature in that research field.\n\n-- research summary begin --\nMy research focuses on EEG-driven closed-loop neuromodulation using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). I am interested in systems that extract real-time features from ongoing EEG and adapt TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters accordingly to modulate brain states. The work broadly concerns algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of EEG–TMS closed-loop paradigms, without committing to a single clinical or cognitive application, outcome metric, or subject population.\n-- research summary end --\n\nThis is NOT a query-generation task.\nThis is a concept-framework construction task.\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Base the framework ONLY on the content explicitly stated or clearly implied in the research summary.\n   - Do NOT introduce new research goals, populations, or application domains.\n   - Do NOT speculate beyond the summary.\n\n2. The output must define a SMALL NUMBER of concept blocks (typically 2–4).\n   - Each block represents a distinct and independently searchable conceptual dimension\nthat should not be merged with other dimensions if doing so would reduce recall.\n   - Examples include: research task, technical field/framing, data modality.\n   - All blocks together must uniquely define ONE narrow research field.\n\nIMPORTANT — Concept Block Separation Rule:\n\nWhen constructing concept blocks, prioritize retrieval independence over semantic compactness.\n\nIf two concepts frequently appear separately in relevant literature\n(e.g., one may be mentioned without the other in titles/abstracts),\nthey MUST be placed in separate concept blocks,\neven if they form a well-known combined phrase or subfield name.\n\nExample:\n- “speech” and “brain-computer interface” must be separate blocks,\n  because many relevant papers mention speech decoding without explicitly using “BCI”,\n  and others mention BCI without explicitly using “speech”.\n\n\n3. Each concept block must:\n   - Contain only terms that are conceptually equivalent within that block.\n   - Be expressed using terminology commonly found in academic databases.\n   - Include common synonyms, abbreviations, and canonical terms used in the literature.\n\n4. When the summary uses abstract or high-level language, normalize it into concrete, database-searchable concepts\n   ONLY when such normalization is standard practice in the field.\n   - Example: “invasive recordings” → ECoG, sEEG, intracortical recordings, MEA\n   - Do NOT introduce loosely related or adjacent techniques.\n\n5. All concept blocks must be REQUIRED.\n   - The framework should be designed for exhaustive retrieval within a specific field,\n     not for exploratory or cross-domain search.\n\n6. Do NOT generate executable Boolean queries.\n   - You MAY describe the logical relationship between blocks conceptually\n     (e.g., “documents must address all blocks simultaneously”),\n     but do not use database syntax.\n\n7. Explicitly prevent topic drift.\n   - The framework should clearly exclude adjacent but distinct research areas.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n### Block B: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n(Repeat blocks as needed)\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nA single sentence explaining how all blocks jointly define the target literature set.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n- Out-of-scope:\n"}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:17:32.702732+00:00", "event": "llm.complete_text.response", "model": "gpt-5.2", "api": "chat/completions", "full_prompt": "You are an expert academic search strategist specializing in exhaustive literature retrieval. \n\nBelow is a short research summary, your task is to take above research summary and directly produce a conceptual retrieval framework that can be used to systematically search for all relevant literature in that research field.\n\n-- research summary begin --\nMy research focuses on EEG-driven closed-loop neuromodulation using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). I am interested in systems that extract real-time features from ongoing EEG and adapt TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters accordingly to modulate brain states. The work broadly concerns algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of EEG–TMS closed-loop paradigms, without committing to a single clinical or cognitive application, outcome metric, or subject population.\n-- research summary end --\n\nThis is NOT a query-generation task.\nThis is a concept-framework construction task.\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Base the framework ONLY on the content explicitly stated or clearly implied in the research summary.\n   - Do NOT introduce new research goals, populations, or application domains.\n   - Do NOT speculate beyond the summary.\n\n2. The output must define a SMALL NUMBER of concept blocks (typically 2–4).\n   - Each block represents a distinct and independently searchable conceptual dimension\nthat should not be merged with other dimensions if doing so would reduce recall.\n   - Examples include: research task, technical field/framing, data modality.\n   - All blocks together must uniquely define ONE narrow research field.\n\nIMPORTANT — Concept Block Separation Rule:\n\nWhen constructing concept blocks, prioritize retrieval independence over semantic compactness.\n\nIf two concepts frequently appear separately in relevant literature\n(e.g., one may be mentioned without the other in titles/abstracts),\nthey MUST be placed in separate concept blocks,\neven if they form a well-known combined phrase or subfield name.\n\nExample:\n- “speech” and “brain-computer interface” must be separate blocks,\n  because many relevant papers mention speech decoding without explicitly using “BCI”,\n  and others mention BCI without explicitly using “speech”.\n\n\n3. Each concept block must:\n   - Contain only terms that are conceptually equivalent within that block.\n   - Be expressed using terminology commonly found in academic databases.\n   - Include common synonyms, abbreviations, and canonical terms used in the literature.\n\n4. When the summary uses abstract or high-level language, normalize it into concrete, database-searchable concepts\n   ONLY when such normalization is standard practice in the field.\n   - Example: “invasive recordings” → ECoG, sEEG, intracortical recordings, MEA\n   - Do NOT introduce loosely related or adjacent techniques.\n\n5. All concept blocks must be REQUIRED.\n   - The framework should be designed for exhaustive retrieval within a specific field,\n     not for exploratory or cross-domain search.\n\n6. Do NOT generate executable Boolean queries.\n   - You MAY describe the logical relationship between blocks conceptually\n     (e.g., “documents must address all blocks simultaneously”),\n     but do not use database syntax.\n\n7. Explicitly prevent topic drift.\n   - The framework should clearly exclude adjacent but distinct research areas.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n### Block B: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n(Repeat blocks as needed)\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nA single sentence explaining how all blocks jointly define the target literature set.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n- Out-of-scope:\n", "raw_response": "## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Real-Time Sensing Modality\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal driving the system (not other neuroimaging/recording modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Real-time/online” may be stated as “on-line,” “real time,” “streaming,” or implied via “closed-loop” descriptions; keep EEG terms independent because some papers mention EEG without explicitly saying “closed-loop” in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts to TMS-based stimulation (not electrical stimulation or other noninvasive stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many relevant papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - Parameter adaptation may be described without the word “adaptive” (e.g., “state-dependent TMS,” “EEG-triggered TMS,” “phase-specific TMS”).\n\n### Block C: Closed-Loop / Adaptive / State-Dependent Control Linking EEG to TMS Delivery\n- Concept Role: Captures the control paradigm where EEG is used to adjust TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters (i.e., feedback-driven or state-dependent stimulation).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Closed-loop” is not always used; “state-dependent,” “EEG-triggered,” or “phase-locked” often serve as the operational description.\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may emphasize “closed-loop control” without naming both modalities prominently in the abstract.\n\n### Block D: Real-Time EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing for Control Decisions\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes algorithmic/signal-processing elements that compute EEG features used to drive TMS adaptation (not merely concurrent EEG+TMS measurement).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - real-time feature extraction\n  - online feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - real-time signal processing\n  - online signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - oscillations / neural oscillations (in EEG context)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power / band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma) (as EEG features)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling (as an EEG-derived feature, if explicitly used)\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (when explicitly tied to EEG-driven control)\n  - detection / event detection (when explicitly EEG-based and used to trigger/adapt TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant papers may describe the algorithm as “detection,” “tracking,” or “state estimation” rather than “feature extraction.”\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into control of stimulation.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG as the real-time measured signal, TMS as the stimulation method, and a closed-loop/adaptive control link in which real-time EEG feature extraction informs TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms.\n  - Systems that compute EEG features online and use them to trigger, time, or adapt TMS pulses and/or stimulation parameters.\n  - Algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of such EEG–TMS closed-loop systems (regardless of application domain, outcome metric, or population).\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently but not used to control stimulation.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for control.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used only for post hoc stratification/targeting without real-time adaptation of TMS delivery.", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "step": "parse"}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:17:32.703780+00:00", "event": "phase1.parse.response", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "model": "gpt-5.2", "response": "## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Real-Time Sensing Modality\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal driving the system (not other neuroimaging/recording modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Real-time/online” may be stated as “on-line,” “real time,” “streaming,” or implied via “closed-loop” descriptions; keep EEG terms independent because some papers mention EEG without explicitly saying “closed-loop” in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts to TMS-based stimulation (not electrical stimulation or other noninvasive stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many relevant papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - Parameter adaptation may be described without the word “adaptive” (e.g., “state-dependent TMS,” “EEG-triggered TMS,” “phase-specific TMS”).\n\n### Block C: Closed-Loop / Adaptive / State-Dependent Control Linking EEG to TMS Delivery\n- Concept Role: Captures the control paradigm where EEG is used to adjust TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters (i.e., feedback-driven or state-dependent stimulation).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Closed-loop” is not always used; “state-dependent,” “EEG-triggered,” or “phase-locked” often serve as the operational description.\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may emphasize “closed-loop control” without naming both modalities prominently in the abstract.\n\n### Block D: Real-Time EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing for Control Decisions\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes algorithmic/signal-processing elements that compute EEG features used to drive TMS adaptation (not merely concurrent EEG+TMS measurement).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - real-time feature extraction\n  - online feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - real-time signal processing\n  - online signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - oscillations / neural oscillations (in EEG context)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power / band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma) (as EEG features)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling (as an EEG-derived feature, if explicitly used)\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (when explicitly tied to EEG-driven control)\n  - detection / event detection (when explicitly EEG-based and used to trigger/adapt TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant papers may describe the algorithm as “detection,” “tracking,” or “state estimation” rather than “feature extraction.”\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into control of stimulation.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG as the real-time measured signal, TMS as the stimulation method, and a closed-loop/adaptive control link in which real-time EEG feature extraction informs TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms.\n  - Systems that compute EEG features online and use them to trigger, time, or adapt TMS pulses and/or stimulation parameters.\n  - Algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of such EEG–TMS closed-loop systems (regardless of application domain, outcome metric, or population).\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently but not used to control stimulation.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for control.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used only for post hoc stratification/targeting without real-time adaptation of TMS delivery."}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:20:55.690138+00:00", "event": "phase1.adjust_framework.prompt", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "model": "gpt-5.2", "reasoning_effort": "high", "prompt_file": "/Users/xiaowu/local_code/scholarmap/prompts/retrival_framework_stage2.md", "prompt": "You are an expert academic search strategist specializing in exhaustive literature retrieval. \n\nYou will receive:\n(1) The current Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n(2) User's adjustment request (user_additional_info) - may contain clarifications, modifications, or additional requirements\n\nYour task is to integrate the user's input with the current framework and produce an updated Conceptual Retrieval Framework that reflects the user's adjustments while maintaining the framework's integrity and searchability.\n\n-- current framework begin --\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Real-Time Sensing Modality\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal driving the system (not other neuroimaging/recording modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Real-time/online” may be stated as “on-line,” “real time,” “streaming,” or implied via “closed-loop” descriptions; keep EEG terms independent because some papers mention EEG without explicitly saying “closed-loop” in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts to TMS-based stimulation (not electrical stimulation or other noninvasive stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many relevant papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - Parameter adaptation may be described without the word “adaptive” (e.g., “state-dependent TMS,” “EEG-triggered TMS,” “phase-specific TMS”).\n\n### Block C: Closed-Loop / Adaptive / State-Dependent Control Linking EEG to TMS Delivery\n- Concept Role: Captures the control paradigm where EEG is used to adjust TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters (i.e., feedback-driven or state-dependent stimulation).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Closed-loop” is not always used; “state-dependent,” “EEG-triggered,” or “phase-locked” often serve as the operational description.\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may emphasize “closed-loop control” without naming both modalities prominently in the abstract.\n\n### Block D: Real-Time EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing for Control Decisions\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes algorithmic/signal-processing elements that compute EEG features used to drive TMS adaptation (not merely concurrent EEG+TMS measurement).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - real-time feature extraction\n  - online feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - real-time signal processing\n  - online signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - oscillations / neural oscillations (in EEG context)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power / band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma) (as EEG features)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling (as an EEG-derived feature, if explicitly used)\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (when explicitly tied to EEG-driven control)\n  - detection / event detection (when explicitly EEG-based and used to trigger/adapt TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant papers may describe the algorithm as “detection,” “tracking,” or “state estimation” rather than “feature extraction.”\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into control of stimulation.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG as the real-time measured signal, TMS as the stimulation method, and a closed-loop/adaptive control link in which real-time EEG feature extraction informs TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms.\n  - Systems that compute EEG features online and use them to trigger, time, or adapt TMS pulses and/or stimulation parameters.\n  - Algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of such EEG–TMS closed-loop systems (regardless of application domain, outcome metric, or population).\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently but not used to control stimulation.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for control.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used only for post hoc stratification/targeting without real-time adaptation of TMS delivery.\n-- current framework end --\n\nuser_additional_info (user's adjustment request):\n\"\"\"The out-of-scope should be adjusted. The offline EEG analysis should also be included.\"\"\"\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Base the updated framework on BOTH the current framework AND the user's adjustment request.\n   - Preserve valid parts of the current framework that are not contradicted by the user's input.\n   - Incorporate the user's adjustments, clarifications, or modifications.\n   - Do NOT introduce entirely new research goals or domains that are not mentioned in either the current framework or user input.\n\n2. The output must define a SMALL NUMBER of concept blocks (typically 2–4).\n   - Each block represents a distinct and independently searchable conceptual dimension\n     that should not be merged with other dimensions if doing so would reduce recall.\n   - Examples include: research task, technical field/framing, data modality.\n   - All blocks together must uniquely define ONE narrow research field.\n\nIMPORTANT — Concept Block Separation Rule:\n\nWhen constructing concept blocks, prioritize retrieval independence over semantic compactness.\n\nIf two concepts frequently appear separately in relevant literature\n(e.g., one may be mentioned without the other in titles/abstracts),\nthey MUST be placed in separate concept blocks,\neven if they form a well-known combined phrase or subfield name.\n\nExample:\n- \"speech\" and \"brain-computer interface\" must be separate blocks,\n  because many relevant papers mention speech decoding without explicitly using \"BCI\",\n  and others mention BCI without explicitly using \"speech\".\n\n3. Each concept block must:\n   - Contain only terms that are conceptually equivalent within that block.\n   - Be expressed using terminology commonly found in academic databases.\n   - Include common synonyms, abbreviations, and canonical terms used in the literature.\n\n4. When the user input or current framework uses abstract or high-level language, normalize it into concrete, database-searchable concepts\n   ONLY when such normalization is standard practice in the field.\n   - Example: \"invasive recordings\" → ECoG, sEEG, intracortical recordings, MEA\n   - Do NOT introduce loosely related or adjacent techniques.\n\n5. All concept blocks must be REQUIRED.\n   - The framework should be designed for exhaustive retrieval within a specific field,\n     not for exploratory or cross-domain search.\n\n6. Do NOT generate executable Boolean queries.\n   - You MAY describe the logical relationship between blocks conceptually\n     (e.g., \"documents must address all blocks simultaneously\"),\n     but do not use database syntax.\n\n7. Explicitly prevent topic drift.\n   - The framework should clearly exclude adjacent but distinct research areas.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n### Block B: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n(Repeat blocks as needed)\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nA single sentence explaining how all blocks jointly define the target literature set.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n- Out-of-scope:\n\n"}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:21:26.362489+00:00", "event": "llm.complete_text.response", "model": "gpt-5.2", "api": "chat/completions", "full_prompt": "You are an expert academic search strategist specializing in exhaustive literature retrieval. \n\nYou will receive:\n(1) The current Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n(2) User's adjustment request (user_additional_info) - may contain clarifications, modifications, or additional requirements\n\nYour task is to integrate the user's input with the current framework and produce an updated Conceptual Retrieval Framework that reflects the user's adjustments while maintaining the framework's integrity and searchability.\n\n-- current framework begin --\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Real-Time Sensing Modality\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal driving the system (not other neuroimaging/recording modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Real-time/online” may be stated as “on-line,” “real time,” “streaming,” or implied via “closed-loop” descriptions; keep EEG terms independent because some papers mention EEG without explicitly saying “closed-loop” in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts to TMS-based stimulation (not electrical stimulation or other noninvasive stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many relevant papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - Parameter adaptation may be described without the word “adaptive” (e.g., “state-dependent TMS,” “EEG-triggered TMS,” “phase-specific TMS”).\n\n### Block C: Closed-Loop / Adaptive / State-Dependent Control Linking EEG to TMS Delivery\n- Concept Role: Captures the control paradigm where EEG is used to adjust TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters (i.e., feedback-driven or state-dependent stimulation).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Closed-loop” is not always used; “state-dependent,” “EEG-triggered,” or “phase-locked” often serve as the operational description.\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may emphasize “closed-loop control” without naming both modalities prominently in the abstract.\n\n### Block D: Real-Time EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing for Control Decisions\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes algorithmic/signal-processing elements that compute EEG features used to drive TMS adaptation (not merely concurrent EEG+TMS measurement).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - real-time feature extraction\n  - online feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - real-time signal processing\n  - online signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - oscillations / neural oscillations (in EEG context)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power / band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma) (as EEG features)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling (as an EEG-derived feature, if explicitly used)\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (when explicitly tied to EEG-driven control)\n  - detection / event detection (when explicitly EEG-based and used to trigger/adapt TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant papers may describe the algorithm as “detection,” “tracking,” or “state estimation” rather than “feature extraction.”\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into control of stimulation.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG as the real-time measured signal, TMS as the stimulation method, and a closed-loop/adaptive control link in which real-time EEG feature extraction informs TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms.\n  - Systems that compute EEG features online and use them to trigger, time, or adapt TMS pulses and/or stimulation parameters.\n  - Algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of such EEG–TMS closed-loop systems (regardless of application domain, outcome metric, or population).\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently but not used to control stimulation.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for control.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used only for post hoc stratification/targeting without real-time adaptation of TMS delivery.\n-- current framework end --\n\nuser_additional_info (user's adjustment request):\n\"\"\"The out-of-scope should be adjusted. The offline EEG analysis should also be included.\"\"\"\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Base the updated framework on BOTH the current framework AND the user's adjustment request.\n   - Preserve valid parts of the current framework that are not contradicted by the user's input.\n   - Incorporate the user's adjustments, clarifications, or modifications.\n   - Do NOT introduce entirely new research goals or domains that are not mentioned in either the current framework or user input.\n\n2. The output must define a SMALL NUMBER of concept blocks (typically 2–4).\n   - Each block represents a distinct and independently searchable conceptual dimension\n     that should not be merged with other dimensions if doing so would reduce recall.\n   - Examples include: research task, technical field/framing, data modality.\n   - All blocks together must uniquely define ONE narrow research field.\n\nIMPORTANT — Concept Block Separation Rule:\n\nWhen constructing concept blocks, prioritize retrieval independence over semantic compactness.\n\nIf two concepts frequently appear separately in relevant literature\n(e.g., one may be mentioned without the other in titles/abstracts),\nthey MUST be placed in separate concept blocks,\neven if they form a well-known combined phrase or subfield name.\n\nExample:\n- \"speech\" and \"brain-computer interface\" must be separate blocks,\n  because many relevant papers mention speech decoding without explicitly using \"BCI\",\n  and others mention BCI without explicitly using \"speech\".\n\n3. Each concept block must:\n   - Contain only terms that are conceptually equivalent within that block.\n   - Be expressed using terminology commonly found in academic databases.\n   - Include common synonyms, abbreviations, and canonical terms used in the literature.\n\n4. When the user input or current framework uses abstract or high-level language, normalize it into concrete, database-searchable concepts\n   ONLY when such normalization is standard practice in the field.\n   - Example: \"invasive recordings\" → ECoG, sEEG, intracortical recordings, MEA\n   - Do NOT introduce loosely related or adjacent techniques.\n\n5. All concept blocks must be REQUIRED.\n   - The framework should be designed for exhaustive retrieval within a specific field,\n     not for exploratory or cross-domain search.\n\n6. Do NOT generate executable Boolean queries.\n   - You MAY describe the logical relationship between blocks conceptually\n     (e.g., \"documents must address all blocks simultaneously\"),\n     but do not use database syntax.\n\n7. Explicitly prevent topic drift.\n   - The framework should clearly exclude adjacent but distinct research areas.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n### Block B: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n(Repeat blocks as needed)\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nA single sentence explaining how all blocks jointly define the target literature set.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n- Out-of-scope:\n\n", "raw_response": "## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Sensing/Analysis Modality (Real-Time or Offline)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal used to derive brain-state information relevant to TMS timing/parameter selection (whether computed online for immediate control or offline for subsequent targeting/stratification).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - resting-state EEG\n  - task EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n  - offline EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Offline” may be described as “post hoc,” “retrospective,” “offline analysis,” or “EEG-informed targeting” without explicitly saying “offline EEG.”\n  - Keep EEG terms independent because some papers emphasize TMS adaptation/targeting while only briefly mentioning EEG in methods.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where TMS is the stimulation modality whose delivery (timing, intensity, pattern, or targeting) is informed by EEG-derived information.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - EEG-informed TMS may be described as “state-dependent TMS” or “phase-specific TMS” without using “adaptive.”\n\n### Block C: EEG-Informed TMS Delivery (Closed-Loop/Online Control OR Offline EEG-Guided Targeting/Personalization)\n- Concept Role: Captures the linkage where EEG-derived information is used to determine or adjust TMS delivery, either (i) in real time (closed-loop/state-dependent triggering) or (ii) via offline EEG analysis that informs later TMS timing/parameters/target selection.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n  - EEG-informed stimulation\n  - EEG-based targeting\n  - EEG-guided targeting\n  - personalized stimulation (when explicitly EEG-based)\n  - stratification (when explicitly EEG-based and used to set TMS delivery)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Offline EEG use is often framed as “EEG biomarkers” or “predictors” used to select stimulation parameters/targets; include such papers only when the EEG result is explicitly used to set or adapt TMS delivery (not merely correlated with outcomes).\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may foreground “closed-loop” or “EEG-guided targeting” without naming both modalities prominently in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block D: EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing Used to Inform TMS (Online or Offline)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes explicit EEG-derived features/biomarkers (computed online or offline) that are used as the basis for TMS triggering, timing, parameter selection, or targeting (not just concurrent EEG recording).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - neural oscillations (EEG)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power\n  - band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (EEG-based)\n  - detection\n  - event detection\n  - biomarker (EEG biomarker)\n  - predictor (EEG-based predictor)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant offline papers may use “biomarker,” “predictor,” or “signature” rather than “feature extraction”; include these when they operationally determine TMS delivery choices.\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into any TMS delivery decision.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG, TMS, an explicit EEG-to-TMS decision linkage (online closed-loop control or offline EEG-guided targeting/personalization), and EEG feature extraction/biomarker derivation used to inform TMS delivery.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms where EEG features are computed online to trigger/time/adapt TMS.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used to select, personalize, or set subsequent TMS parameters (e.g., timing rules, intensity, protocol choice) and/or stimulation targets, provided the EEG-derived feature is explicitly used to determine TMS delivery.\n  - Algorithmic methods for EEG feature extraction (online or offline) that directly inform TMS delivery decisions, including experimental validation.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS with no EEG-informed decision-making (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently.\n  - Studies where EEG is analyzed offline only for post hoc interpretation/correlation with outcomes, without being used to set or adapt any aspect of TMS delivery.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for the control/targeting decision.", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "step": "adjust_framework"}
{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:21:26.369417+00:00", "event": "phase1.adjust_framework.response", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "model": "gpt-5.2", "response": "## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Sensing/Analysis Modality (Real-Time or Offline)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal used to derive brain-state information relevant to TMS timing/parameter selection (whether computed online for immediate control or offline for subsequent targeting/stratification).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - resting-state EEG\n  - task EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n  - offline EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Offline” may be described as “post hoc,” “retrospective,” “offline analysis,” or “EEG-informed targeting” without explicitly saying “offline EEG.”\n  - Keep EEG terms independent because some papers emphasize TMS adaptation/targeting while only briefly mentioning EEG in methods.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where TMS is the stimulation modality whose delivery (timing, intensity, pattern, or targeting) is informed by EEG-derived information.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - EEG-informed TMS may be described as “state-dependent TMS” or “phase-specific TMS” without using “adaptive.”\n\n### Block C: EEG-Informed TMS Delivery (Closed-Loop/Online Control OR Offline EEG-Guided Targeting/Personalization)\n- Concept Role: Captures the linkage where EEG-derived information is used to determine or adjust TMS delivery, either (i) in real time (closed-loop/state-dependent triggering) or (ii) via offline EEG analysis that informs later TMS timing/parameters/target selection.\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n  - EEG-informed stimulation\n  - EEG-based targeting\n  - EEG-guided targeting\n  - personalized stimulation (when explicitly EEG-based)\n  - stratification (when explicitly EEG-based and used to set TMS delivery)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Offline EEG use is often framed as “EEG biomarkers” or “predictors” used to select stimulation parameters/targets; include such papers only when the EEG result is explicitly used to set or adapt TMS delivery (not merely correlated with outcomes).\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may foreground “closed-loop” or “EEG-guided targeting” without naming both modalities prominently in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block D: EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing Used to Inform TMS (Online or Offline)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes explicit EEG-derived features/biomarkers (computed online or offline) that are used as the basis for TMS triggering, timing, parameter selection, or targeting (not just concurrent EEG recording).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - neural oscillations (EEG)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power\n  - band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (EEG-based)\n  - detection\n  - event detection\n  - biomarker (EEG biomarker)\n  - predictor (EEG-based predictor)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant offline papers may use “biomarker,” “predictor,” or “signature” rather than “feature extraction”; include these when they operationally determine TMS delivery choices.\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into any TMS delivery decision.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG, TMS, an explicit EEG-to-TMS decision linkage (online closed-loop control or offline EEG-guided targeting/personalization), and EEG feature extraction/biomarker derivation used to inform TMS delivery.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms where EEG features are computed online to trigger/time/adapt TMS.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used to select, personalize, or set subsequent TMS parameters (e.g., timing rules, intensity, protocol choice) and/or stimulation targets, provided the EEG-derived feature is explicitly used to determine TMS delivery.\n  - Algorithmic methods for EEG feature extraction (online or offline) that directly inform TMS delivery decisions, including experimental validation.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS with no EEG-informed decision-making (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently.\n  - Studies where EEG is analyzed offline only for post hoc interpretation/correlation with outcomes, without being used to set or adapt any aspect of TMS delivery.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for the control/targeting decision."}
