{"ts": "2026-01-03T03:24:18.918883+00:00", "event": "llm.complete_text.response", "model": "gpt-5.2", "api": "chat/completions", "full_prompt": "You are an expert academic search strategist specializing in exhaustive literature retrieval. \n\nYou will receive:\n(1) The current Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n(2) User's adjustment request (user_additional_info) - may contain clarifications, modifications, or additional requirements\n\nYour task is to integrate the user's input with the current framework and produce an updated Conceptual Retrieval Framework that reflects the user's adjustments while maintaining the framework's integrity and searchability.\n\n-- current framework begin --\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Real-Time Sensing Modality\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature uses EEG as the measured signal driving the system (not other neuroimaging/recording modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - real-time EEG\n  - online EEG\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Real-time/online” may be stated as “on-line,” “real time,” “streaming,” or implied via “closed-loop” descriptions; keep EEG terms independent because some papers mention EEG without explicitly saying “closed-loop” in titles/abstracts.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Neuromodulation/Actuation Method\n- Concept Role: Restricts to TMS-based stimulation (not electrical stimulation or other noninvasive stimulation modalities).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - TMS pulse timing\n  - stimulation parameters (in the context of TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Many relevant papers use “TMS” without spelling out the full term; include both.\n  - Parameter adaptation may be described without the word “adaptive” (e.g., “state-dependent TMS,” “EEG-triggered TMS,” “phase-specific TMS”).\n\n### Block C: Closed-Loop / Adaptive / State-Dependent Control Linking EEG to TMS Delivery\n- Concept Role: Captures the control paradigm where EEG is used to adjust TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters (i.e., feedback-driven or state-dependent stimulation).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - “Closed-loop” is not always used; “state-dependent,” “EEG-triggered,” or “phase-locked” often serve as the operational description.\n  - Keep this block separate from EEG and TMS because papers may emphasize “closed-loop control” without naming both modalities prominently in the abstract.\n\n### Block D: Real-Time EEG Feature Extraction / Signal Processing for Control Decisions\n- Concept Role: Ensures the work includes algorithmic/signal-processing elements that compute EEG features used to drive TMS adaptation (not merely concurrent EEG+TMS measurement).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - feature extraction\n  - real-time feature extraction\n  - online feature extraction\n  - signal processing\n  - real-time signal processing\n  - online signal processing\n  - EEG features\n  - oscillations / neural oscillations (in EEG context)\n  - phase (EEG phase)\n  - power / band power\n  - spectral power\n  - frequency band (alpha, beta, theta, gamma) (as EEG features)\n  - phase–amplitude coupling (as an EEG-derived feature, if explicitly used)\n  - state estimation\n  - brain-state tracking\n  - classifier (when explicitly tied to EEG-driven control)\n  - detection / event detection (when explicitly EEG-based and used to trigger/adapt TMS)\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Relevant papers may describe the algorithm as “detection,” “tracking,” or “state estimation” rather than “feature extraction.”\n  - This block is intended to exclude purely descriptive EEG analyses that do not feed into control of stimulation.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG as the real-time measured signal, TMS as the stimulation method, and a closed-loop/adaptive control link in which real-time EEG feature extraction informs TMS timing and/or stimulation parameters.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG-driven closed-loop (feedback/state-dependent) TMS paradigms.\n  - Systems that compute EEG features online and use them to trigger, time, or adapt TMS pulses and/or stimulation parameters.\n  - Algorithmic control, signal processing, and experimental validation of such EEG–TMS closed-loop systems (regardless of application domain, outcome metric, or population).\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - Open-loop TMS (fixed schedules) even if EEG is recorded concurrently but not used to control stimulation.\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (e.g., tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly the stimulation method.\n  - Non-EEG sensing modalities driving stimulation (e.g., MEG, fMRI, NIRS) unless EEG is explicitly used for control.\n  - Offline EEG analysis used only for post hoc stratification/targeting without real-time adaptation of TMS delivery.\n-- current framework end --\n\nuser_additional_info (user's adjustment request):\n\"\"\"Below should be included:\nStudies where EEG is analyzed offline only for post hoc interpretation/correlation with outcomes, without being used to set or adapt any aspect of TMS delivery.\"\"\"\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Base the updated framework on BOTH the current framework AND the user's adjustment request.\n   - Preserve valid parts of the current framework that are not contradicted by the user's input.\n   - Incorporate the user's adjustments, clarifications, or modifications.\n   - Do NOT introduce entirely new research goals or domains that are not mentioned in either the current framework or user input.\n\n2. The output must define a SMALL NUMBER of concept blocks (typically 2–4).\n   - Each block represents a distinct and independently searchable conceptual dimension\n     that should not be merged with other dimensions if doing so would reduce recall.\n   - Examples include: research task, technical field/framing, data modality.\n   - All blocks together must uniquely define ONE narrow research field.\n\nIMPORTANT — Concept Block Separation Rule:\n\nWhen constructing concept blocks, prioritize retrieval independence over semantic compactness.\n\nIf two concepts frequently appear separately in relevant literature\n(e.g., one may be mentioned without the other in titles/abstracts),\nthey MUST be placed in separate concept blocks,\neven if they form a well-known combined phrase or subfield name.\n\nExample:\n- \"speech\" and \"brain-computer interface\" must be separate blocks,\n  because many relevant papers mention speech decoding without explicitly using \"BCI\",\n  and others mention BCI without explicitly using \"speech\".\n\n3. Each concept block must:\n   - Contain only terms that are conceptually equivalent within that block.\n   - Be expressed using terminology commonly found in academic databases.\n   - Include common synonyms, abbreviations, and canonical terms used in the literature.\n\n4. When the user input or current framework uses abstract or high-level language, normalize it into concrete, database-searchable concepts\n   ONLY when such normalization is standard practice in the field.\n   - Example: \"invasive recordings\" → ECoG, sEEG, intracortical recordings, MEA\n   - Do NOT introduce loosely related or adjacent techniques.\n\n5. All concept blocks must be REQUIRED.\n   - The framework should be designed for exhaustive retrieval within a specific field,\n     not for exploratory or cross-domain search.\n\n6. Do NOT generate executable Boolean queries.\n   - You MAY describe the logical relationship between blocks conceptually\n     (e.g., \"documents must address all blocks simultaneously\"),\n     but do not use database syntax.\n\n7. Explicitly prevent topic drift.\n   - The framework should clearly exclude adjacent but distinct research areas.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n### Block B: [Concept Block Name]\n- Concept Role:\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n\n(Repeat blocks as needed)\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nA single sentence explaining how all blocks jointly define the target literature set.\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n- Out-of-scope:\n\n", "raw_response": "## Conceptual Retrieval Framework\n\n### Block A: Electroencephalography (EEG) as the Neural Measurement Modality (Concurrent with TMS Studies)\n- Concept Role: Ensures the literature involves EEG recording/analysis in the context of TMS studies (including both real-time and offline EEG analysis).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - concurrent EEG\n  - simultaneous EEG\n  - TMS-EEG\n  - EEG-TMS\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include “TMS-EEG / EEG-TMS” because many papers index the combined methodology rather than describing EEG and TMS separately in titles/abstracts.\n  - Do not require “real-time/online” EEG wording here, because the updated scope includes offline/post hoc EEG analyses.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Stimulation/Intervention Modality\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where TMS is the stimulation method (regardless of whether stimulation is open-loop or closed-loop).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - theta burst stimulation\n  - TBS\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include common protocol labels (e.g., rTMS, TBS) because many studies foreground protocol names rather than the generic “TMS” phrase.\n\n### Block C: EEG–TMS Linkage for Either (i) Closed-Loop Control OR (ii) Offline/Post Hoc EEG Outcome Interpretation\n- Concept Role: Captures the required relationship between EEG and TMS: either EEG is used to control/trigger/adapt TMS delivery (closed-loop/state-dependent) OR EEG is analyzed offline/post hoc to interpret, correlate with, or predict TMS effects/outcomes (without controlling delivery).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n  - offline analysis\n  - post hoc analysis\n  - post-hoc analysis\n  - correlation\n  - association\n  - predictor\n  - prediction\n  - biomarker\n  - outcome\n  - treatment response\n  - response prediction\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - This block is intentionally broadened to include studies where EEG is *not* used to set/adapt TMS delivery but is analyzed *afterward* for interpretation/correlation with outcomes.\n  - “Biomarker,” “predictor,” and “treatment response” are included to capture common framing of post hoc EEG–outcome relationships in TMS studies.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG (Block A) and TMS (Block B) and explicitly link EEG to TMS either through closed-loop/state-dependent control or through offline/post hoc EEG interpretation/correlation with TMS effects or outcomes (Block C).\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG recorded in TMS studies where EEG is used online to trigger/time/adapt TMS (closed-loop/state-dependent EEG–TMS).\n  - EEG recorded in TMS studies where EEG is analyzed offline/post hoc to interpret TMS effects, correlate EEG features with outcomes, or predict response—without EEG influencing TMS delivery.\n  - Methodological and experimental papers using TMS-EEG where the EEG–TMS linkage is explicitly framed as control or outcome interpretation/prediction.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - TMS studies with EEG recorded only as a concurrent measurement with no explicit EEG–TMS linkage (i.e., neither control nor post hoc interpretation/correlation/prediction is described).\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly used.\n  - Studies where the control signal is exclusively non-EEG (MEG, fMRI, fNIRS, EMG) unless EEG is also explicitly used for the control/interpretation linkage.\n  - Purely technical EEG signal-processing papers not situated in a TMS intervention context.", "project_id": "6af7ac1b6254", "run_id": "53e099cdb74e", "step": "adjust_framework"}

Purely technical EEG signal-processing papers not situated in a TMS intervention context."}

electroencephalography\n  - EEG\n  - scalp EEG\n  - ongoing EEG\n  - concurrent EEG\n  - simultaneous EEG\n  - TMS-EEG\n  - EEG-TMS\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include “TMS-EEG / EEG-TMS” because many papers index the combined methodology rather than describing EEG and TMS separately in titles/abstracts.\n  - Do not require “real-time/online” EEG wording here, because the updated scope includes offline/post hoc EEG analyses.\n\n### Block B: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as the Stimulation/Intervention Modality\n- Concept Role: Restricts retrieval to studies where TMS is the stimulation method (regardless of whether stimulation is open-loop or closed-loop).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - transcranial magnetic stimulation\n  - TMS\n  - rTMS\n  - single-pulse TMS\n  - paired-pulse TMS\n  - theta burst stimulation\n  - TBS\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - Include common protocol labels (e.g., rTMS, TBS) because many studies foreground protocol names rather than the generic “TMS” phrase.\n\n### Block C: EEG–TMS Linkage for Either (i) Closed-Loop Control OR (ii) Offline/Post Hoc EEG Outcome Interpretation\n- Concept Role: Captures the required relationship between EEG and TMS: either EEG is used to control/trigger/adapt TMS delivery (closed-loop/state-dependent) OR EEG is analyzed offline/post hoc to interpret, correlate with, or predict TMS effects/outcomes (without controlling delivery).\n- Normalized Search Terms:\n  - closed-loop\n  - closed loop\n  - feedback control\n  - adaptive stimulation\n  - state-dependent stimulation\n  - brain-state dependent\n  - EEG-triggered stimulation\n  - EEG-guided stimulation\n  - phase-locked stimulation\n  - phase-targeted stimulation\n  - event-triggered stimulation\n  - real-time control\n  - online control\n  - offline analysis\n  - post hoc analysis\n  - post-hoc analysis\n  - correlation\n  - association\n  - predictor\n  - prediction\n  - biomarker\n  - outcome\n  - treatment response\n  - response prediction\n- Notes on Term Usage:\n  - This block is intentionally broadened to include studies where EEG is *not* used to set/adapt TMS delivery but is analyzed *afterward* for interpretation/correlation with outcomes.\n  - “Biomarker,” “predictor,” and “treatment response” are included to capture common framing of post hoc EEG–outcome relationships in TMS studies.\n\n## Conceptual Combination Rule\nDocuments must simultaneously involve EEG (Block A) and TMS (Block B) and explicitly link EEG to TMS either through closed-loop/state-dependent control or through offline/post hoc EEG interpretation/correlation with TMS effects or outcomes (Block C).\n\n## Scope Control\n- In-scope:\n  - EEG recorded in TMS studies where EEG is used online to trigger/time/adapt TMS (closed-loop/state-dependent EEG–TMS).\n  - EEG recorded in TMS studies where EEG is analyzed offline/post hoc to interpret TMS effects, correlate EEG features with outcomes, or predict response—without EEG influencing TMS delivery.\n  - Methodological and experimental papers using TMS-EEG where the EEG–TMS linkage is explicitly framed as control or outcome interpretation/prediction.\n- Out-of-scope:\n  - TMS studies with EEG recorded only as a concurrent measurement with no explicit EEG–TMS linkage (i.e., neither control nor post hoc interpretation/correlation/prediction is described).\n  - Closed-loop neuromodulation using non-TMS actuators (tDCS/tACS/tES, DBS, VNS) unless TMS is explicitly used.\n  - Studies where the control signal is exclusively non-EEG (MEG, fMRI, fNIRS, EMG) unless EEG is also explicitly used for the control/interpretation linkage.\n  - Purely technical EEG signal-processing papers not situated in a TMS intervention context.\n-- Conceptual Retrieval Framework end --\n\n\nYou must follow these rules strictly:\n\n1. Do NOT reinterpret, merge, or split any concept blocks.\n   - Treat each concept block as an independent retrieval dimension.\n   - Preserve the block structure exactly as given.\n\n2. For each concept block:\n   - Combine all normalized search terms within that block using OR.\n   - Apply PubMed field tags consistently, using Title/Abstract fields\n     unless a term is a standard abbreviation or acronym.\n\n3. Across concept blocks:\n   - Combine blocks using AND.\n   - The final query must require that all blocks are satisfied simultaneously.\n\n4. Do NOT introduce new search terms, synonyms, or expansions.\n   - Use ONLY the terms explicitly listed in the framework.\n\n5. Phrase handling:\n   - Multi-word terms must be enclosed in double quotation marks.\n   - Singular/plural variations should be preserved as given; do not infer new ones.\n\n6. PubMed field usage:\n   - Use [Title/Abstract] for most terms.\n   - Acronyms (e.g., BCI, ECoG, iEEG) may be used without field tags\n     only if they are standard and unambiguous.\n   - Do NOT use MeSH terms in this step.\n\n7. If a block contains usage constraints (e.g., “only when paired with X”),\n   enforce this by block-level AND logic, not by modifying individual terms.\n\n8. Output formatting:\n   - Clearly label each block’s query segment.\n   - Provide the final combined PubMed query in a single code block.\n   - Do NOT include explanatory text outside the required output format.\n\n### Output Format (must follow exactly):\n\n## PubMed Query Blocks\n\n### Block A Query\n(query text)\n\n### Block B Query\n(query text)\n\n(Repeat for each block)\n\n## Final Combined PubMed Query\n```text\n(full PubMed query)\n"}
